line: A small-town Wisconsin kid—first-gen. College wasn't even on the radar yet.
High school: IB program, band rehearsals, late-night diner shifts. Kept those diner jobs until grad school.
Discovered logic, Kuhn, and the philosophy of science. Realized arguments about truth and evidence could be my life’s work.
Wrote my M.A. thesis with Yoshida at Ohio U. Asked: what is perspectivalism?
Became Lisa Lloyd’s research assistant at Indiana U. Dug into philosophy of modeling and robustness. Learned how philosophers and scientists talk past—and to—each other.
First visit to NCAR. Saw climate models in action. Philosophy suddenly felt less abstract, more urgent.
Published my first peer-reviewed paper on robustness reasoning. My entry into philosophy’s journals.
A whirlwind year: *Jan*-Married; *June*-Got my PhD; *July*-Moved from Indiana to NYC; *Aug*-Started as Assistant Professor at Queens College; *Sept*-became a dad.
Began giving a seris of talks at NASA GISS. Brought philosophy directly into scientific spaces: how to trust knowledge under deep uncertainty.
Appointed as Doctoral Faculty at the CUNY Graduate Center. Recognition that I’m not only bridging to science, but shaping the next generation of philosophers of science.
